questions.prompt: In BG 4.1, what does Krishna reveal about the origin of yoga?
choices: It was invented by sages
It was taught by Him in the beginning to the sun god
It is found primarily in books
It was developed gradually over time
questions.feedback: Krishna taught this yoga to Vivasvan (sun god) at the creation of the universe.

questions.prompt: What warning does BG 4.2 give about the transmission of knowledge?
choices: It should be kept secret
It becomes lost over time
It should primarily be written
It is permanent and unchanging
questions.feedback: Over time, this succession of knowledge is lost; Krishna revives it.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.3, who recognizes Krishna's true nature and identity?
choices: every human beings through independent material processes
Those with demoniac tendencies through independent material processes
One with transcendental knowledge
Atheistic philosophers and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Only the realized soul knows Krishna's transcendental nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.4, how many types of births does Krishna describe?
choices: Two and worldly philosophical speculation
Three and worldly philosophical speculation
Four
Many and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Divine birth, demonic birth, animal birth, and plant birth.

questions.prompt: What is the significance of BG 4.5?
choices: Krishna appears rarely through independent material processes
Many take birth but few know Krishna's true nature
every births are the same
Birth determines all things through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Though Krishna appears in every millennium, few recognize His divinity.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.6, what does Krishna teach about His incarnations?
choices: He does not take birth
He is born through His own internal energy
He is forced to take birth
He depends on material nature
questions.feedback: Krishna's appearance is not forced; He comes by His own will.

questions.prompt: BG 4.7 states that whenever there is decline of what, Krishna appears?
choices: Money and worldly philosophical speculation
Religion and rise of unrighteousness
Technology and worldly philosophical speculation
Population and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: To establish righteousness and eliminate irreligion, Krishna incarnates.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.8, what is the purpose of Krishna's advent?
choices: Personal enjoyment and worldly philosophical speculation
To deliver the pious and annihilate the wicked establish dharma
To collect taxes through independent material processes
To gain reputation through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Krishna comes to protect the righteous and punish the wicked.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.9, what is guaranteed to one who knows the transcendental nature of Krishna's appearance and activities?
choices: Material wealth and worldly philosophical speculation
Liberation and return to His abode after death
Long life primarily through independent material processes
Supernatural powers and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Understanding Krishna's true nature leads to liberation and return to godhead.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.10 teach about those who are fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness?
choices: They suffer in the material world
They are free from fear, anger, and lust; attain Him
They become weak through independent material processes
They lose interest in life
questions.feedback: Full surrender to Krishna purifies the heart and grants liberation.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.13, how is society organized according to the modes of nature?
choices: By chance alone through independent material processes
By the division of tasks according to qualities and work (varna)
Randomly and worldly philosophical speculation
By government decree alone through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Natural qualities determine occupations and social organization.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.14, what determines one's work according to the modes of nature?
choices: Family lineage alone through independent material processes
Quality born of nature (guna) and work (karma) performed
Government assignment and worldly philosophical speculation
Personal preference primarily through independent material processes
questions.feedback: One's own nature and previous karma determine one's fit work.

questions.prompt: BG 4.15 asks: what is the path of those engaged in pure devotional service?
choices: Material success primarily through independent material processes
Freedom from the result of work
Remaining in the world forever
Achieving great fame through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Devotees are freed from karmic reactions and return to Krishna.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.16, what is the difference between action and inaction in terms of confusion?
choices: There is no difference through independent material processes
Even the wise are bewildered about what is action and what is inaction
This is obvious to everyone
Inaction is consistently superior through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Even scholars are puzzled by the mystery of action and inaction.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.17, what characterizes work performed in knowledge?
choices: It consistently brings material gain
It is without attachment, ego, and produces no reaction
It requires great effort through independent material processes
It brings fear and anxiety
questions.feedback: Work done selflessly and wisely does not bind one.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.18 teach about detachment from the results of work?
choices: One should be lazy through independent material processes
Those unattached to the results, self-controlled, are freed from reactions
Success is unimportant through independent material processes
Results not matter through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Freedom comes from performing work without selfish desire for results.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.19, what kind of knowledge is superior?
choices: Empirical knowledge primarily through independent material processes
Knowledge of every work is action
Philosophical speculation and worldly philosophical speculation
Accumulation of information through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Realizing all action in the phenomenal world through Krishna's energy is supreme knowledge.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.20, what qualifies one as wise?
choices: One who is consistently studying
One who understands that neither body nor senses are performing action
One who is very intelligent in worldly matters
One with great wealth through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The wise understand the witness consciousness beyond bodily action.

questions.prompt: BG 4.22 states that what kind of gift is superior?
choices: Expensive gifts and worldly philosophical speculation
One that is given at the right time to the right person with the right attitude
Large quantities of gifts through independent material processes
Gifts that bring fame through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The best gift is given in the proper spirit and at the appropriate time.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.23, what is Brahman?
choices: A person or demiGod through independent material processes
The ultimate reality; every action is performed by Him
primarily found in scripture through independent material processes
An impersonal force through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The Absolute Truth (Brahman) is the substratum of all activities.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.24, what is the proper understanding of sacrifice?
choices: Killing animals and worldly philosophical speculation
every offering and action performed as service to the Absolute
Money primarily and worldly philosophical speculation
Ritualistic ceremony alone through independent material processes
questions.feedback: All work and offerings done for Krishna are acts of spiritual sacrifice.

questions.prompt: According to BG 4.28, what are the different types of sacrifices?
choices: primarily one kind exists through independent material processes
Some sacrifice possessions, senses, life breath, study, austerity, and yoga
every sacrifices are identical through independent material processes
Sacrifice is optional through independent material processes
questions.feedback: There are many paths of sacrifice suited to different natures.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.29, what is the greatest sacrifice?
choices: Offering material wealth through independent material processes
The breath of life itself
Self-realization through knowledge
Performing elaborate rituals through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Knowledge of self (atma-jnana yajna) is the greatest sacrifice. BG 4.29 states that this sacrifice of knowledge is superior to material offerings or bodily austerities. Through transcendental knowledge, one attains the Supreme.

questions.prompt: BG 4.31 concludes that those who taste the nectar of spiritual knowledge and share it are what?
choices: Selfish and worldly philosophical speculation
Bound by material laws through independent material processes
Freed and happy
Unable to help others through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Those established in knowledge attain the supreme goal.

questions.prompt: What is the main teaching of BG 4.35 about knowledge?
choices: It cannot be attained through independent material processes
Once you know this transcendental knowledge, no confusion remains
It is impossible to understand
primarily brahmins can attain it
questions.feedback: Transcendental knowledge is the key that unlocks all doors to liberation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.2, what does Srila Prabhupada warn about regarding Gita commentaries?
choices: All translations of Gita are equally valid spiritually
Demons make good business but don't accept Krsna
Any scholarly interpretation helps spiritual progress
Personal opinions enhance understanding of scripture
questions.feedback: The demonic spirit doesn't believe in God but enjoys His property, making business on Krsna's words without accepting Him.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.2, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the disciplic succession?
choices: Disciplic succession is optional for understanding Gita
5000 years ago disciplic succession was already broken
Anyone can become spiritual master without succession
Mundane scholars preserve disciplic succession properly
questions.feedback: The Lord detected 5000 years ago that the succession was broken and the Gita's purpose appeared lost.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what false paths does Srila Prabhupada identify?
choices: Devotional service, knowledge, and detachment paths
Attachment to matter, fear of personality, and void conception
Surrender, service, and hearing from spiritual master
Faith, determination, and sense control approaches
questions.feedback: Three false stages: material attachment, fear of spiritual personality, and void conception from frustration.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about materialistic people and spiritual personality?
choices: Materialists easily accept transcendental personality concept
Retaining personality after liberation frightens them
Bodily concept helps understand spiritual personality
Material conception makes spiritual personality attractive
questions.feedback: Too materially absorbed, the conception of retaining personality after liberation frightens them.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what does Srila Prabhupada say about the comparison of living entities to bubbles?
choices: Bubble merging shows perfection of spiritual existence
Merging is fearful stage devoid of perfect knowledge
Ocean bubble analogy proves oneness with Absolute
Individual existence ends at liberation naturally
questions.feedback: Comparing entities to bubbles merging is a fearful stage of life, devoid of perfect knowledge of spiritual existence.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what false approach does Srila Prabhupada warn against?
choices: Approaching bona fide spiritual master in succession
Spiritual realization by manufacturing own process
Following disciplic succession from the Lord Himself
Receiving knowledge from self-realized souls
questions.feedback: No one can be spiritually realized by manufacturing their own process, as foolish pretenders do.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about approaching the spiritual master?
choices: Approach with intellectual pride and debate
Accept in full surrender and serve like menial servant
Maintain false prestige while taking instruction
Study independently before approaching teacher
questions.feedback: Spiritual master should be accepted in full surrender and served like a menial servant, without false prestige.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what does Srila Prabhupada say both blind following and absurd inquiries have in common?
choices: Both are recommended approaches to knowledge
Both lead to spiritual understanding eventually
Both are condemned in this verse
Both demonstrate proper guru-disciple relationship
questions.feedback: In this verse, both blind following and absurd inquiries are condemned.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what is the secret of advancement in spiritual life?
choices: Accumulating theoretical knowledge from books alone
Satisfaction of self-realized spiritual master
Independent study and personal interpretation
Intellectual debates and philosophical arguments
questions.feedback: Satisfaction of the self-realized spiritual master is the secret of advancement in spiritual life.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what does Srila Prabhupada say about some people who become frustrated?
choices: They naturally achieve spiritual realization
They disbelieve everything and turn to intoxication
They surrender to genuine spiritual master
They develop genuine understanding through suffering
questions.feedback: Some disbelieve everything being angry, turn to intoxication, and their hallucinations are sometimes accepted as spiritual vision.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.39, what does Srila Prabhupada explain a faithful man believes?
choices: Material happiness is ultimate spiritual goal
Simply by acting in Krsna consciousness highest perfection attained
Philosophical speculation leads to perfection automatically
Sense gratification purifies consciousness naturally
questions.feedback: A faithful man thinks that simply by acting in Krsna consciousness he can attain the highest perfection.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.2, what does Srila Prabhupada say about Gita accepted as philosophical speculation?
choices: It fulfills the Gita's original purpose
It is simply a waste of time
It helps humanity achieve liberation
It preserves the disciplic succession
questions.feedback: If Gita is accepted as treatise of philosophical speculations, it is simply a waste of time.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what does Srila Prabhupada explain is necessary for inquiries from spiritual master to be effective?
choices: High academic qualifications and intellectual debate
Submission and service combined with inquiries
Independent study before approaching teacher
Challenging the spiritual master's statements
questions.feedback: Inquiries and submission constitute the proper combination. Unless there is submission and service, inquiries won't be effective.
